text: <https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2590174519300157> -- Aluminion RedOx cycle as an energy store. If my math isn't off, the ~500kg/apartment stated in the paper would be a cube of ~60cm per side. This doesn't feel correct, where is the catch?

text: I'll read this paper in depth after work. One of the big reasons why Hydrogen fuel's haven't taken off is they are highly flammable.

text: I doesnt seem very useful to have aluminum as a way of storing energy, The process is about 25% efficient and you have to ship 500Kg aluminum blocks everywhere, reducing the efficiency even further. IMO the easiest way to store large amounts of energy are reversible hydroelectric powerplants
